domains.name: Product Definition
domains.description: Artifacts and decisions that define the Product’s strategic direction, value promise, market intent, scope boundaries, and the high-level functional structure that will later be elaborated into requirements.

terms.name: Product Vision
terms.definition: A clear, aspirational description of the future state of the Product that guides strategic decisions by expressing what the Product aims to become.
terms.description: Defines the intended future state and long-range ambition, serving as a stable anchor for scope, prioritization, and roadmap decisions without prescribing implementation details.

terms.name: Product Mission
terms.definition: A concise statement describing the core purpose of the Product, including the fundamental problem it solves and the impact it intends to create.
terms.description: Clarifies the Product’s purpose in one statement, keeping teams aligned on what the Product exists to achieve and why it matters.

terms.name: Product Positioning
terms.definition: A defined message describing what the Product is, who it is for, and why it matters, used to align communication, branding, and launch messaging.
terms.description: Sets a shared, consistent way to describe the Product externally and internally, ensuring messaging aligns with target market intent and differentiation.

terms.name: Value Proposition
terms.definition: A precise description of the unique benefit the Product offers, why it is valuable, and why users should choose it over alternatives.
terms.description: States the Product’s core promise and why it wins against alternatives, forming the basis for positioning, prioritization, and launch messaging.

terms.name: Customer Value Mapping
terms.definition: A structured identification of the specific benefits the Product provides to each Target Market or user segment.
terms.description: Maps which user segments get which benefits, making value explicit per segment and supporting prioritization and positioning consistency.

terms.name: Differentiators
terms.definition: Specific characteristics or advantages that set the Product apart from competitors or substitute solutions.
terms.description: Lists what is meaningfully better or unique, enabling clear competitive messaging and guiding capability and feature prioritization.

terms.name: Competitive Positioning
terms.definition: The defined strategic placement of the Product relative to alternatives, stating how it should compete and what differentiates its Customer Value in the market.
terms.description: Defines the chosen competitive stance and the basis for winning, aligning differentiators and value proposition into a coherent competitive strategy.

terms.name: Target Markets
terms.definition: The primary customer segments and audiences the Product is built for, guiding commercial choices, feature prioritization, and positioning.
terms.description: Defines which markets and segments are in scope for the Product, constraining commercial decisions and focusing roadmap and backlog priorities.

terms.name: Commercial Model
terms.definition: The structure defining how the Product generates value and revenue, including Target Markets, Revenue Streams, Pricing Strategy, and Monetization.
terms.description: Defines how the Product makes money and how usage converts into revenue, providing constraints for scope decisions and roadmap sequencing.

terms.name: Business Goals
terms.definition: Measurable business outcomes the Product is expected to achieve, describing why the Product is being developed from a business perspective.
terms.description: Defines the business outcomes that justify investment and guide prioritization, ensuring the Product’s direction remains tied to measurable impact.

terms.name: Success Metrics
terms.definition: Specific measurable indicators used to evaluate whether the Product is achieving desired outcomes.
terms.description: Specifies how success will be measured, enabling validation of progress and preventing ambiguous interpretation of outcomes.

terms.name: Strategic Product Scope
terms.definition: A defined boundary describing what the Product will include and will not include in its strategic direction, preventing uncontrolled expansion.
terms.description: Sets explicit scope boundaries to reduce scope creep and to keep roadmap and backlog decisions aligned with the Product’s intended direction.

terms.name: Capability Areas
terms.definition: High-level functional clusters that represent major abilities of the Product and group related features and requirements into coherent domains.
terms.description: Defines the Product’s top-level functional structure used to organize later requirements, experience design, and delivery planning.

terms.name: Epics
terms.definition: Large, high-level functional units that represent substantial product deliverables and contain multiple Features and User Stories.
terms.description: Provides a delivery-sized grouping for major outcomes, bridging strategic intent with later feature and story decomposition.

terms.name: Initial Feature Set
terms.definition: An early, non-exhaustive list of high-level functional capabilities planned for the Product, aligned with Strategic Product Scope and Epics before detailed requirements exist.
terms.description: Establishes an initial view of what will be built at a high level, enabling early prioritization and alignment before requirements elaboration.

terms.name: High Level Product Roadmap
terms.definition: A time-oriented plan showing the sequence of major Product milestones, Epics, and Capability Areas, providing an overview of when key parts will be delivered.
terms.description: Defines sequencing of major outcomes and milestones, aligning strategy with delivery expectations at a high level.

terms.name: Launch Objectives
terms.definition: Defined goals for the initial release of the Product specifying what must be achieved at the moment of launch.
terms.description: Specifies what “ready to launch” means in measurable terms for the first release, informing roadmap scope and acceptance focus.

terms.name: Long Term Direction
terms.definition: A documented perspective of how the Product should evolve over an extended time horizon, defining future orientation and expansion areas.
terms.description: Provides a long-horizon evolution view that guides roadmap shaping and prevents short-term decisions from blocking intended growth.

terms.name: Prioritization Foundations
terms.definition: The initial set of rules, factors, and criteria used to establish how early backlog items will be prioritized before formal frameworks are applied.
terms.description: Defines how early prioritization decisions are made using value, feasibility, dependencies, and effort considerations, creating consistent ordering logic for the initial backlog.
